price_objections.objection: Your price is higher than other framers I've talked to
price_objections.underlying_concern: Am I overpaying or being taken advantage of?
price_objections.authentic_response: I appreciate you being upfront about that. Here's what I want you to consider: the difference in our price reflects three things that save you money overall. First, we'll be done in [X] days versus the typical [Y] days, which means you're paying other trades to wait around less. Second, we pass inspection the first time - no costly rework or schedule delays. Third, our material waste runs about [X]% versus the industry average of [Y]%. When you factor in the total project cost and timeline, most builders find we actually cost them less. Can I show you a breakdown of where that value comes from on your specific project?
price_objections.reframe: Shift from framing cost to total project cost and timeline impact

trust_objections.objection: I've been burned by framers before who didn't finish the job
trust_objections.underlying_concern: How do I know you won't disappear or let me down?
trust_objections.authentic_response: I completely understand that concern - I've heard too many horror stories from builders. Here's how we're different: we only take on projects we can fully staff and complete. Before we commit to your timeline, I'll show you our current schedule and crew availability so you can see exactly where your project fits. We also provide weekly progress updates and you'll have my cell number for any concerns. I'd also like to connect you with [X] builders we're currently working for so you can ask them directly about our reliability. Would that help give you confidence?
trust_objections.reframe: Acknowledge pain, provide transparency and verification mechanisms

timing_objections.objection: I need someone who can start immediately and you're booked out
timing_objections.underlying_concern: My project can't wait and I'll lose money sitting idle
timing_objections.authentic_response: I hear the urgency and I don't want your project sitting idle either. Let me see what I can do - sometimes we have a project that can shift by a week, or we can bring in an additional crew lead for the right fit. Can you tell me your absolute drop-dead start date? Also, I want to be honest: if we rush to start before we're ready, neither of us wins. I've seen projects start 'immediately' with crews that are stretched too thin, and it ends up taking longer and costing more. If I genuinely can't meet your timeline, I'd rather refer you to [another quality framer] than set us both up for failure. Let me check our schedule and get back to you within 24 hours with real options.
timing_objections.reframe: Show flexibility while maintaining quality standards and offering alternatives

scope_objections.objection: I just need basic framing, nothing fancy - this seems like overkill
scope_objections.underlying_concern: Am I paying for expertise I don't need?
scope_objections.authentic_response: Fair point - let's make sure we're aligned on what you actually need. Walk me through the plans. [Review together] Okay, so you're right that the floor plan is straightforward, but I'm seeing engineered lumber here, a cathedral ceiling detail, and this load-bearing beam that requires specific hardware. What looks 'basic' actually has some technical elements that need to be done right or you'll have problems down the road. We can absolutely adjust our approach for straightforward sections, but cutting corners on the technical parts will cost you more in the long run. How about we price it in phases so you can see where the complexity actually is?
scope_objections.reframe: Educate on hidden complexity while respecting their assessment

relationship_objections.objection: I've used the same framer for years - why would I switch?
relationship_objections.underlying_concern: Change feels risky when current relationship works well enough
relationship_objections.authentic_response: That loyalty tells me you value good relationships - and honestly, if your current framer is meeting your needs, you shouldn't switch. I'm not here to poach good working relationships. But I'm curious what made you take this call? [Listen] Okay, so it sounds like [capacity/timing/specialization] is the gap. Rather than thinking about switching, what if we positioned ourselves as your backup crew or specialist for [specific need]? That way you keep your primary relationship but have a reliable option when [situation occurs]. Many of our best builder relationships started that way - they tested us on one project while keeping their main crew, and it evolved from there. Would that feel like a safer way to explore working together?
relationship_objections.reframe: Position as complement rather than replacement, reduce switching risk

quality_objections.objection: How do I know your quality is actually better than what I'm getting now?
quality_objections.underlying_concern: Quality claims are just marketing - prove it
quality_objections.authentic_response: You shouldn't just take my word for it. Here's what I propose: come visit two of our active job sites this week - unannounced if you want. Look at the framing details, check the corners for square, look at how we handle headers and connections. Bring your level and tape measure. Then call the builders and ask them specifically about our inspection pass rate and if they've had to call us back for corrections. I'll also show you our inspection reports from the last 10 projects. If you don't see a clear difference in quality, then we're probably not the right fit for what you value. Fair enough?
quality_objections.reframe: Invite verification through observable evidence, not claims

The #1 reason framing projects fall behind schedule isn't weather, labor shortages, or material delays.

It's poor sequencing.

After managing framing operations for [NUMBER] years across [NUMBER]+ projects, I've identified the 5 critical sequence points that make or break your timeline:

1. FOUNDATION VERIFICATION BEFORE DELIVERY
Don't order lumber until you've verified foundation dimensions. We caught a 4" discrepancy last month that would've cost 3 days of rework and $[AMOUNT] in wasted materials.

2. MATERIAL STAGING BY PHASE
Stage first floor materials separately from second floor. Sounds obvious, but I see crews digging through entire lumber packages daily, wasting 2+ hours per day.

3. WALL ASSEMBLY BEFORE SHEATHING DELIVERY
Frame and stand walls before sheathing arrives. Sheathing on-site creates congestion and slows wall assembly by 40%.

4. ROUGH OPENINGS CONFIRMED WITH WINDOW SCHEDULE
Verify window/door schedules before framing. We build ROs to actual unit dimensions, not plan dimensions. This eliminated our callback rate for opening adjustments.

5. INSPECTION SCHEDULING BEFORE SHEATHING
Schedule your framing inspection before you sheath. Some jurisdictions require visual access to framing members. Knowing this saves potential sheathing removal.

thread_structure: I once framed an entire second story 2 inches too low. Cost me $11,000 to fix. Here's what I learned 🧵
Year 3 in business. Got cocky. Didn't double-check the plans. Just eyeballed the ceiling height.
Inspector shows up: 'Your ceiling height is 7'10". Code requires 8'0" minimum.' My stomach dropped.
Options were brutal: 1) Lower the first floor (impossible), 2) Raise the entire second floor, 3) Start over.
We raised it. Jacked the whole thing up, added 2 inches everywhere. Took 9 days. Lost $11k between labor and delay penalties.
The lesson: ALWAYS verify critical dimensions against plans. Even if you've done it 1000 times.
Now we have a 3-person check system for all critical measurements. Haven't had an issue since.

twitter_content_templates.hook_tweet: 7 framing mistakes I see on EVERY job site (and how to avoid them) 🧵
thread_structure: 7 framing mistakes I see on EVERY job site (and how to avoid them) 🧵
1. Not checking for crown on studs. Install crown UP on floor joists, crown OUT on wall studs. Prevents floor sag and wall bowing.
2. Overdriving nails. Your nail gun isn't a jackhammer. Flush is perfect, countersunk weakens connections by 40%.
3. Ignoring the layout. 16" OC means ON CENTER, not 16" from edge to edge. Rookie mistake that causes drywall headaches.
4. Wrong fastener schedule. 3" nails for studs, 3.5" for plates. Using the wrong size fails inspection every time.
5. Not accounting for shrinkage. Wet lumber shrinks. We always use kiln-dried or factor in 1/8" per floor for settling.
6. Skipping the sill seal. $30 in foam seal prevents $3,000 in moisture damage. Easy choice.
7. Rushing the layout. Spend 2 hours on perfect layout, save 10 hours on corrections. Measure twice, frame once.

thread_structure: Client asked why framing costs more than finishing. I showed them this. They never questioned the price again 🧵
Framing holds up literally everything. If we mess up, the entire house fails. That's not an exaggeration.
Every wall must be: Plumb (perfectly vertical), Level (perfectly horizontal), Square (90° corners), AND structurally sound.
We're working with: Load calculations, span tables, engineering specs, building codes, wind ratings, seismic requirements.
Meanwhile we're: 30 feet in the air, in 95° heat, racing weather, coordinating with 6 other trades.
Compare to painting: Important? Yes. Holds up the house? No. Requires structural engineering? No.
The skill gap is massive. It takes 5+ years to become a lead framer. You can learn to paint well in 6 months.
So when you're paying $45/sq ft for framing vs $3/sq ft for paint, you're paying for expertise that keeps your family safe.
